expanded_description: A system of linear equations consists of two or more linear equations considered together. The solution to a system is the ordered pair (or pairs) that satisfies all equations simultaneously. Graphing is the most visual method for solving systems—the solution is the point where the lines intersect. This method provides intuition about the nature of the solution before moving to algebraic methods.

core_concept.principle: To solve a system of two linear equations by graphing: (1) Graph each line on the same coordinate plane. (2) Find the point where the lines intersect. (3) The intersection point $(x, y)$ is the solution to the system. If the lines are parallel, there is no solution. If the lines are the same (coincident), there are infinitely many solutions.
core_concept.explanation: Think of each equation as a path. The solution to a system is where the paths cross—the one place you can stand that's on both paths simultaneously. If the paths never cross (parallel lines), there's no common point. If the paths are the same line (coincident), every point on that line is a common point—infinitely many solutions.

sections.introduction: A system of equations is a set of two or more equations that share variables. We look for values that make all equations true at the same time.

introduction_image.alt: Two equations with brace, showing they are considered together
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.1.2: A system of equations.

key_concept.definition:
A system of linear equations is a collection of linear equations involving the same variables. For two variables, a system looks like:
$\begin{cases} a_1x + b_1y = c_1 \\ a_2x + b_2y = c_2 \end{cases}$
The solution is an ordered pair $(x, y)$ that makes both equations true.
key_concept.context: Systems model situations where multiple conditions must be satisfied simultaneously—like finding the price of two items when you know total costs from different combinations.

image.alt: Example system: 2x + y = 5 and x - y = 1
image.caption: Figure 7.1.3: A sample system.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Solutions to Systems

image.caption: Figure 7.1.4: Determine if each ordered pair is a solution.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether $(2, 1)$ is a solution to each system:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + y = 5 \\ x - y = 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} x + 2y = 4 \\ 3x - y = 5 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 4x - y = 7 \\ 2x + y = 3 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation: Second equation not satisfied → not a solution

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Yes, b) Yes, c) No
worked_examples.concept_applied: An ordered pair is a solution to a system only if it satisfies ALL equations in the system.

sections.introduction: Before solving systems by graphing, let's quickly review how to graph linear equations accurately.

key_concept.definition:
To graph a line, you can use:
• Slope-intercept form $y = mx + b$: plot y-intercept, use slope to find another point.
• Standard form $Ax + By = C$: find intercepts by setting $x=0$ and $y=0$.
• Two points: plot any two points that satisfy the equation.
key_concept.context: Accuracy in graphing is essential for finding correct intersection points.

worked_examples.title: Graphing Lines for Systems
worked_examples.problem:
Graph each line on a separate coordinate plane:
a) $y = 2x - 1$
b) $3x + 2y = 12$
c) $x - 2y = 4$

step_by_step.explanation: Y-intercept at $(0,-1)$, slope $2 = \frac{2}{1}$ → from (0,-1), right 1, up 2 to (1,1)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Accurate graphing is essential for finding correct intersection points.

sections.introduction: The solution to a system of two linear equations is the point where their graphs intersect.

introduction_image.alt: Two lines intersecting at a point
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.1.13: The intersection point is the solution.

key_concept.definition: To solve a system by graphing: (1) Graph both lines on the same coordinate plane. (2) Identify the point where they intersect. (3) The coordinates of that point $(x, y)$ are the solution. (4) Check by substituting into both original equations.
key_concept.context: Graphing gives a visual understanding of the solution and is especially useful for checking work done by other methods.

image.alt: Step-by-step process for solving by graphing
image.caption: Figure 7.1.14: Solving by graphing process.

worked_examples.title: Solving a System by Graphing
worked_examples.problem:
Solve the system by graphing:
$\begin{cases} y = 2x - 1 \\ y = -x + 5 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Y-intercept at $(0,-1)$, slope $2$ → from (0,-1), right 1, up 2 to (1,1)
Y-intercept at $(0,5)$, slope $-1$ → from (0,5), right 1, down 1 to (1,4)
The lines appear to intersect at $(2,3)$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph both lines; the intersection point is the solution. Always check by substitution.

worked_examples.title: System with Fractions
worked_examples.problem:
Solve the system by graphing:
$\begin{cases} y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \\ 2x - 3y = 6 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Y-intercept at $(0,1)$, slope $\frac{1}{2}$ → from (0,1), right 2, up 1 to (2,2)

step_by_step.calculation: Y-intercept at $(0,-2)$, slope $\frac{2}{3}$ → from (0,-2), right 3, up 2 to (3,0)

step_by_step.explanation: The lines appear to intersect at $(6,4)$
$2(6) - 3(4) = 12 - 12 = 0$, but second equation equals 6? Wait, check: $2(6) - 3(4) = 12 - 12 = 0 \neq 6$
step_by_step.calculation: So (6,4) is NOT on second line. Let's find correct intersection.

worked_examples.final_answer: The correct intersection is $(18, 10)$. This shows that graphing can sometimes lead to estimation errors; always check your solution.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graphing gives an estimate; always verify algebraically, especially with fractional coordinates.

process_flow.description: Graph the first line accurately using slope-intercept or intercept method.
process_flow.mechanism: Choose points that are easy to plot accurately.

process_flow.description: Graph the second line on the same coordinate plane.
process_flow.mechanism: Use the same scale and be precise.
process_flow.result: Both lines on the same plane.

process_flow.description: Locate the point where the two lines cross.
process_flow.mechanism: Read the coordinates as accurately as possible.

process_flow.description: Substitute the coordinates into both original equations.
process_flow.mechanism: If they satisfy both, the solution is correct.

sections.section_title: 7.1.4 Special Cases: Parallel and Coincident Lines
sections.introduction: Not all systems have a single intersection point. Some have no solution, while others have infinitely many.

key_concept.definition:
When graphing a system:
• If the lines intersect at exactly one point, the system has one unique solution (consistent and independent).
• If the lines are parallel (same slope, different intercepts), they never intersect → no solution (inconsistent).
• If the lines are the same (coincident), they intersect at every point → infinitely many solutions (consistent and dependent).
key_concept.context: Recognizing these cases from the equations without graphing is a skill we'll develop, but graphing makes them visually obvious.

image.caption: Figure 7.1.27: The three possible outcomes.

classifications.behavior: Exactly one ordered pair satisfies both equations.

examples.explanation: Different slopes → intersect at one point

classifications.behavior: No ordered pair satisfies both equations.

examples.explanation: Same slope, different intercepts → parallel, no solution

classifications.behavior: Every point on the line satisfies both equations.

worked_examples.title: Identifying from Equations

image.caption: Figure 7.1.32: Classify each system without graphing.

worked_examples.problem:
Without graphing, determine whether each system has one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 3 \\ y = 2x - 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ y = -x + 4 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} y = \frac{1}{2}x + 2 \\ 2y = x + 4 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation: Same slope, different intercepts → parallel → no solution
Same as first equation → coincident → infinite solutions

worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) One solution, c) Infinite solutions
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare slopes and intercepts to determine the type of system.

sections.introduction: Sometimes intersection points have coordinates that are not integers. In such cases, we estimate the solution from the graph.

key_concept.definition: When intersection points fall between grid lines, we estimate their coordinates as accurately as possible. This is one limitation of the graphing method—algebraic methods give exact solutions.
key_concept.context: Estimation is acceptable when an approximate answer is sufficient, or as a check on algebraic methods.

worked_examples.title: Estimating a Solution
worked_examples.problem: The graph shows two lines intersecting. Estimate the coordinates of the intersection point to the nearest half-unit.

step_by_step.explanation: The point appears about halfway between 1 and 2
The point appears just below 3, about 0.2 below

worked_examples.concept_applied: When intersection isn't at grid lines, estimate as accurately as possible.

sections.introduction: One common real-world application of systems is finding break-even points, where cost equals revenue.

key_concept.definition: In business, the break-even point is where total cost equals total revenue. This can be found by graphing the cost function $C(x)$ and revenue function $R(x)$ and finding their intersection. The x-coordinate is the number of units to break even; the y-coordinate is the break-even amount.
key_concept.context: This is one of the most practical applications of systems of equations.

worked_examples.title: Break-Even Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A company has cost function $C(x) = 15x + 200$ and revenue function $R(x) = 25x$. Find the break-even point by graphing.

step_by_step.explanation: $R(x) = 25x$: through $(0,0)$, slope $25$ → from (0,0), right 10, up 250 to (10,250)
The lines appear to intersect at $(20, 500)$

worked_examples.final_answer: Break-even at 20 units, with cost and revenue both $\$500$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Break-even is where cost equals revenue; graph both and find intersection.

summary: Solving systems of linear equations by graphing involves graphing each line on the same coordinate plane and finding their intersection point. This point $(x, y)$ is the solution—the values that satisfy both equations simultaneously. The graphing method visually reveals the three possible outcomes: intersecting lines (one unique solution), parallel lines (no solution), and coincident lines (infinitely many solutions). To graph accurately, use slope-intercept form or the intercept method, and always check your solution by substituting back into the original equations. When intersection points have non-integer coordinates, estimate as accurately as possible. Real-world applications include finding break-even points where cost equals revenue. While graphing provides intuition and visual understanding, it has limitations—accuracy depends on precise graphing, and non-integer solutions are only estimated. In the following sections, we'll learn algebraic methods that give exact solutions.
